subsection_content_2: .  Earlier this week, officials confirmed four outbreaks of H5N1 in Pagretar VDC of Sindhupalchowk district.  To prevent the disease from spreading further, 1,300 chickens were destroyed, and officials are urging farmers throughout the country to notify their veterinarians if they notice any sick or dead birds, as the flu virus has been detected at more than half a dozen poultry farms throughout the area.
subsection_content_1: .  According to the Italian veterinary authorities , three outbreaks of H7N7 have been confirmed at turkey farms in the Italian province of Ferrara.  Out of 19,850 susceptible turkeys, 1,300 birds died after contracting the virus.  The birds were first sampled on the 19th of August with negative results, but later tests confirmed the H7 virus.  To prevent the disease from spreading further, restriction zones have been established around the affected farms and the control measures being applied include quarantine, movement control throughout the country, and depopulation.
subsection_content_3: .  Health officials at the Teaching Hospital of College of Medical Sciences in Bharatpur suspect that the H5N1 virus is the cause of the recent deaths of two women.  Both women presented with common cold-like symptoms, and after “the twin deaths”, authorities believe that the women were infected with the virus; however, no samples were collected from either of the victims.  At the same hospital, another female patient is suffering from similar symptoms.  The woman, who lives near the Nawalparasi district, where a number of cases of bird flu cases have been confirmed, has been given Tamiflu and throat and nasal swabs were collected.  Health officials hope to have the results back in one week.
